It's a valid point but personally I think there's a big difference.   In the example of Dennis Smith Jr, this is a player that got shipped out to... New York. And remember, a player like that still has plenty of opportunity to prove that they deserve to be in the NBA. Whether that be through practice, other players getting injured, or even in garbage time. Then the years go by and this is what happened to their career. There's a ton of soccer teams and leagues in the world and trust me, this happens *a lot*.   When you think about soccer, it's such a global sport that you can imagine a single league in the same realm of like A, AA, AAA, and MLB in baseball. Except for instead of 4 there's like 200 each with their own reputation and skill level.

I always think that you need to evaluate a pick relative to the players who could have been picked in that spot. There's always going to be someone better taken way deeper in the draft, but the point is usually that NOBODY saw that guy coming. So with Kendall Marshall, both John Henson and Mo Harkless had better careers, and they were the next two picks. That makes it a clear bad pick. (IN fact, four of the next five picks had better careers. Oof.)  On the other hand, Alex Len - you look at the next few picks, and they're not clearly better than Alex Len by a large margin until you get to CJ McColumn.
